description: After downloading the application, go into the terminal. Type in "spotify-qt" it should open up into a window. click the dashboard link, it has on there. Sign in to your spotify account and hit "create app." Name it whatever you want, and after you create it should show you client id/ show secret id (both you need). I forgot which link you click on the spotify dashboard, but follow the directions on the window and set the redirect window to the link provided on the window. Then you're good. I'm not affiliated with the people that created this app, but I do appreciate it. The spotify app for ubuntu can't run on my rasberry pi 4 due to the arm64 architecture. There is a tiny issue. I can't play the music out of the computer, it does however, lets me control my spotify on other devices. If I try to play a song without playing on my phone or any other device, spotify-qt shows "No device found." BUT this is the only app that worked so far at least to an extent, thanks bud!
i just dont get it how people take the time to write "it doesnt work" when they can use that time instead to figure out how to make it work
Seriously tho, learn to troubleshoot before posting a bad review.
summary: It works, people just don't know how to troubleshoot

description: The software installed and opened, but was hard to get it to find anything to play.
Great App, was tricky to start (spend 10 min, it is my first day of using linux). But easy to use! Trank to developers!
Local devicenot found. Could only connect to my cellularphone. Useless
seems that i cant get it to open fix this please

It was tricky to get working, but that turned out to be issues with spotifyd, not with spotify-qt itself. I could find devices when connected to the official spotify app, or on my phone, but could not get spotifyd working through snap - I eventually managed to get it to see the spotifyd device when I compiled spotifyd from source, but even then, I still ahd to start spotifyd manually (or have it run permanently as a service) and could not get it set up in the Spotify section of the Settings menu.

There are also no clear, easy to follow instructions for getting it all working.

Once it was working, the app is OK, but there are still a few annoyances:

There's a full second or two delay when pressing the pause button before the music stops playing, and there's another second or so before the pause button updates to the play icon. Not a big deal, but it does put a damper on the user experience.

Secondly, I could not find a way to get it to respond to media keys or global shortcuts. This is a deal breaker for me.

That said, the developer seems quite active on Github and seems to be working on removing the need for a separate client. If that happens, this app has a lot of potential.
summary: Real issues are with spotifyd and snap

description: This is a SUPERB app, though takes some time to open. I read the reviews below and decided to check it out. You require a Spotify Premium to stream, which is quite a burn. Thus, I recommend it to ppl with that.
Just like spotify (well it probaly is ) a tiny bit slow but no lag!
ДРАЧУ КАЙФУЮ ПУТИН ГЕЙ
ДРААААЧУУ КАЙФУУУУЮЮ. ПУТИН ГЕЙ. ЗЕЛЕНСКИЙ ПРОСТО ТЯНКА-СЕКСУАЛКА

the setup requires logging in to a Spotify developer account (included with every Spotify paid account) and relatively complicated setup, but kinda fun and satisfying. Once it's set up though, the app is very lightweight and easy to use. Not the full Spotify experience, but the interface is very similar to Rhythmbox.
summary: complicated setup, but works great after
